articles.headline: Facebook will pay up to $14 million to settle claims it favored foreign workers.
articles.snippet: The Justice Department sued the company in December, arguing that Facebook had declined to “recruit, consider or hire” qualified United States workers for more than 2,000 positions.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department sued the company in December, arguing that Facebook had declined to “recruit, consider or hire” qualified United States workers for more than 2,000 positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facebook agreed on Tuesday to pay up to $14.25 million to settle claims brought by the federal government in the waning days of the Trump administration that the company had discriminated against United States workers.

articles.headline: Trump’s Pentagon Chief Quashed Idea to Send 250,000 Troops to the Border
articles.snippet: Top national security aides to former President Trump also talked him out of launching military raids against drug cartels inside Mexico.
articles.abstract: Top national security aides to former President Trump also talked him out of launching military raids against drug cartels inside Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s defense secretary thought the idea was outrageous.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Michael D. Shear and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: House Panel Recommends Contempt Charge Against Bannon
articles.snippet: The committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6 Capitol riot said the former White House counselor had “multiple roles relevant to this investigation.”
articles.abstract: The committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6 Capitol riot said the former White House counselor had “multiple roles relevant to this investigation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day before a mob of former President Donald J. Trump’s supporters stormed the Capitol, Stephen K. Bannon, a former top adviser to Mr. Trump, made a prediction to listeners of his radio show.

articles.headline: Small Needles and Short Lines: Biden’s Plan to Vaccinate Young Children
articles.snippet: White House officials, anticipating the approval of coronavirus shots for 5- to 11-year-olds within weeks, will rely on doctors, clinics and pharmacies instead of mass inoculation sites.
articles.abstract: White House officials, anticipating the approval of coronavirus shots for 5- to 11-year-olds within weeks, will rely on doctors, clinics and pharmacies instead of mass inoculation sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The campaign to vaccinate young children in the United States against the coronavirus will not look like the adult version. There will be no mass inoculation sites. Pediatricians will be enlisted to help work with parents. Even the vials — and the needles to administer doses — will be smaller.

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg will be added to a Facebook privacy lawsuit.
articles.snippet: The District of Columbia case, which grew out of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, could expose the chief executive to financial and other penalties.
articles.abstract: The District of Columbia case, which grew out of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, could expose the chief executive to financial and other penalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attorney general for the District of Columbia on Wednesday added Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, to a consumer protection lawsuit, in one of the first efforts by a regulator to expose him personally to potential financial and other penalties. The attorney general, Karl Racine, said that continuing interviews and reviews of internal documents for the case had revealed that Mr. Zuckerberg played a much more active role in key decisions than prosecutors had known.

articles.headline: Boris Johnson Claims a Positive in Britain’s Shortages. Economists Disagree.
articles.snippet: Wages in some industries are rising because employers can’t find enough workers. That’s not a path to long-term growth, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Wages in some industries are rising because employers can’t find enough workers. That’s not a path to long-term growth, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a country bedeviled by acute shortages of goods and workers, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is portraying the chaos as a source of national revival.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Eshe Nelson

articles.headline: Afghan Women Who Once Presided Over Abuse Cases Now Fear for Their Lives
articles.snippet: They fear that they or their loved ones could be tracked down and killed because of their work delivering justice to women. “We have lost everything — our jobs, our homes, the way we lived.”
articles.abstract: They fear that they or their loved ones could be tracked down and killed because of their work delivering justice to women. “We have lost everything — our jobs, our homes, the way we lived.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When Nabila was a judge in Afghanistan’s Supreme Court, she granted divorces to women whose husbands were sometimes jailed for assaulting or kidnapping them. Some of the men threatened to kill her after they had served their time, she said.

articles.headline: How Chemical Companies Avoid Paying for Pollution
articles.snippet: DuPont factories pumped dangerous substances into the environment. The company and its offspring have gone to great lengths to dodge responsibility.
articles.abstract: DuPont factories pumped dangerous substances into the environment. The company and its offspring have gone to great lengths to dodge responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — One humid day this summer, Brian Long, a senior executive at the chemical company Chemours, took a reporter on a tour of the Fayetteville Works factory.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Biden Backs Compromise to Win a Vast Social Agenda
articles.snippet: The president’s trip to Scranton, Pa., comes as Democrats close in on a deal to advance two bills carrying a scaled-back version of his domestic policy priorities.
articles.abstract: The president’s trip to Scranton, Pa., comes as Democrats close in on a deal to advance two bills carrying a scaled-back version of his domestic policy priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he tries to steer his party toward a vast, once-in-a-generation investment in social programs, President Biden is paring back his ambitions for clean energy, access to college and help for families.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
